**Short answer**

| Energy source | Estimated deaths / terawatt‑hour (TWh) of electricity generated* | Main cause of those deaths |
|---------------|-----------------------------------|----------------------------|
| **Coal (including mining, plant operation and downstream air‑pollution)** | **≈ 10 – 30 deaths / TWh** (most studies quote ~ 24 deaths/TWh) | Air‑pollution‑related cardiovascular & respiratory disease; mining accidents; occupational exposure |
| **Nuclear (including mining, plant construction, operation and major accidents)** | **≈ 0.04 – 0.07 deaths / TWh** (range 0.01‑0.2) | Rare severe accidents (Chernobyl, Fukushima) plus a very small number of occupational/utility‑worker deaths |

\*A TWh = the amount of electricity generated in one year by a 114 MW plant running at full capacity. The figures are “deaths per unit of *electricity* produced”, not per unit of fuel extracted.

In plain language, **coal kills roughly 300–600 times more people per unit of electricity than nuclear does**. The gap widens if you include the long‑term health burden of fine‑particulate (PM₂.5) and other pollutants that coal releases into the atmosphere.

## 1.  From capacity (GW) to electricity produced (TWh / yr)

*Why the difference?* Nuclear reactors run at a higher, more stable output because they are not limited by fuel‑stockpiling, weather, or frequent start‑stop cycles that many coal plants experience.
